bioghist.p: Mazie Beatrice Hall (1902-2006) was a community leader and educator. She lived in Wayne, Pennsylvania and taught at Powell School in Camden, New Jersey for 23 years. She began teaching in Trenton in 1924 at the New Lincoln School, and in 1935, she got a job as a substitute teacher in Camden. She was a graduate of Westchester State College, where she received a teaching certificate in 1924. She was a member of the Eta chapter of the Phi Delta Kappa sorority. She was a member of the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women Club, and served as the president of the Main Line chapter. She was a member of the Second Baptist Church in Wayne, and in the 1970s, she was secretary of the Pulpit Committee, and was involved in the selection of a new pastor for the church.

scopecontent.p: This collection of papers of Mazie Beatrice Hall comprises magazines, programs and pamphlets, correspondence, and artifacts. Magazines collected by Hall include: Ebony (1960s-1980s), Essence, Black Enterprise, American Visions, Jet, Negro History Bulletin, and Crisis, a Record of the Darker Races (1919-1920 and 1950-1969). There are a number of programs and schedules for meetings of the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Club (NANBPW) and the Phi Delta Kappa sorority; funeral announcements and memorial pamphlets; and a memorial booklet honoring Hall's "75 years of service" to her church. The correspondence in the collection largely consists of seasonal and birthday greeting cards and thank you notes. There is a small amount of personal correspondence from family, friends, and students, and some letters related to Hall's involvement with the NANBPW and to the selection of a new pastor for her church. Artifacts include clothing, shoes, hats, purses, and a banner for the NANBPW. The collection also includes a small number of photographs of Hall and others, two college notebooks; newspaper clippings on topics related to civil rights, education, and local Wayne news; several books; calendars; sheet music; and a commonplace book.
